title: Quantity - a few, few, a little or a little - 2
instructions: Complete the sentences with B1a fewB2, B1fewB2, B1a littleB2 or B1littleB2.

sentence: space in the car boot, so you can bring your fishing tackle.
remarks: Corr: a little. The fact that 'you can bring the fishing tackle', means that there's enough space, so only 'a little' is correct as 'space' is uncountable.

sentence: words in this dictionary. I need a bigger one.
remarks: Corr: few. The number of words in the dictionary is not enough, and 'words' is countable, so only 'few' is correct.
Corr: little. There's not enough time and 'time' is uncountable, so only 'little' is correct.

sentence: people visiting the restaurant. That's why it was closed.
remarks: Corr: few. The number of people was not enough and 'people' is countable, so only 'few' is okay here.

sentence: CDs, so please ask someone else to play music at your party.
remarks: Corr: few. The speaker doesn't have enough CDs and 'CDs' is countable, so 'few' is correct here only.

sentence: furniture in her bedroom. There's only a bed, nothing more.
remarks: Corr: little. The speaker wants to say that the amount of furniture is not much, so only 'little' is correct here. The word 'furniture' is uncountable.

sentence: sugar in my tea that I couldn't drink it at all.
remarks: Corr: little. Definitely there was not enough sugar in the tea, and as 'sugar' is uncountable, only 'little' is good here.

sentence: free time, practically I'm always busy.
remarks: Corr: little. The speaker wants to express that he or she doesn't have enough free time, so only 'little' is correct here. The word 'time' is uncountable.

sentence: good pubs in this part of town. We can choose one of those.
remarks: Corr: a few. The sentence does not imply that there aren't enough pubs, so we have to use 'a few'.

sentence: times, yet they still don't know each other's names.
remarks: Corr: a few. The sentence says they have met enough times to each other's names, yet they don't. So we have to use 'a few'. The word 'times' here means 'occasions', so it's countable.
